title: Spanish supermarkets secretly hoarding massive stockpiles of vegetables despite British shoppers facing RATIONING
text:
TIP OF THE ICEBERG Spanish supermarkets secretly hoarding massive stockpiles of vegetables despite British shoppers facing RATIONING 
Bad weather has wiped out stocks of veg for Brit customers, but in Spain shelves are heaving with greens By NEAL BAKER Comments SPANISH supermarkets are hoarding veg while British shoppers looking for their five-a-day face rationing. 
Bad weather on the continent has devastated crops — but it seems the impact is mainly being felt here in Blighty. Getty Images Shops in Spain have been seen heaving with fresh produce while Brits are going without (Stock image) PA:Press Association Supermarket shelves in the UK are being stripped of veg as people are panic buying PA:Press Association Iceberg lettuce stocks have been badly hit by weather problems in Spain PA:Press Association Supermarkets have brought in rationing to try to counter the problem 
Shop shelves in Spain have been seen heaving with fresh veg like lettuce, courgettes and broccoli. 
But in the UK supermarkets have bare chillers and customers are being stopped from bulk-buying items. 
The rationing comes amid concerns shoppers are panic buying vegetables, wiping out what little stock remains. 
It has also led to a black market for greens, with one farmer offering a box of twelve iceberg lettuces for a staggering £50 . 
Asda has banned customers from buying more than six of each item while online sales of veg at several supermarkets is being blocked to ensure enough stock for their stores. 
Tesco is limiting customers to three iceberg lettuces, while Morrisons is stopping shoppers buying more than three heads of broccoli. 
Ocado has warned it is considering limiting what customers can buy, while Sainsbury’s, Waitrose and Asda’s websites said they had sold out of several items of veg. The shortage began due to bad weather in Spain when snow and storms battered the southern eastern area of Murcia. 
The region produced 80 per cent of vegetables sold in the UK during winter. 
Italy has also been affected by a cold snap, meaning the region is having to import more produce that it would expect at this time of year. PA:Press Association Bad weather in Europe has devastated crops PA:Press Association
